area_name: Big and Small Crack Areas "AKA Lefty Wall"

content.description: Climb the broken finger crack in the dihedral.
content.protection: TR recommended, but I suppose it could be led on gear.  Use trees at the top for anchors.  See Walk Up in the Book area for top access info.
content.location: This is the dihedral at the right end of the area.

content.description: Start with a high hand match on the ledge a few feet below the first bolt. Stay on or slightly right of the bolt line before the big ledge. Avoid using the crack to the left of the route. The fifth bolt is a glue-in just above the big ledge and is optional. Be careful when clipping the anchors as a fall could land on the big ledge.
content.location: Just right of the big crack.

content.description:
Climb the first half of "the Flake". After the second bolt head up and left onto the face.  

  Most the route is about 5.6. The pronounced crux is one or two moves after the second bolt. Hit the third and traverse left to the anchors of "Campbell"
content.location: Left of the dirty corner. Start on the big flake

content.description: Fun moderate climb. Bouldery start with some more difficult moves 10 feet from the top.
content.protection: There are four bolts. With two permadraws as anchors
content.location: Just left of The Big Crack

content.description: Start at a broken ledge and work straight up a few crimps and solid jugs to a sweet mega jug at the 3rd bolt. Move through cool side-pulls, under clings, and more jugs to the anchors.
content.location: Right of El Sasa Beach and left of Campbell

content.description: Climb the left facing flake, left of the dihedral crack.  Join the dihedral near the top.
content.protection: TR.  Anchor on trees above, reached by hiking over from the top of the right end of the crag.  See the Book area.
content.location: On the right end of the crag, just left of the dihedral.

content.description:
Start at a broken ledge and then work with hidden holds on less than vertical terrain to a crux before the third bolt. Tricky sloppers and crimps give way to solid jugs and slightly more than vertical climbing to the anchors.  

  Named after the scummiest beach of South Africa.

Either stick clip or scramble up the small ledge to reach for the first bolt. Then move left and up with the flake for two more. After clipping the third bolt traverse through a short crux right and up to the anchors.
content.protection:
3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with permadraws or

TR on tree above
content.location: Just left of the really dirty dihedral where the TR route "the Flake" is. Look for clean white rock.

content.description: Climb the twin crack system.  Fun.
content.protection: TR recommended, but it could be led.  Use trees at the top for anchors.  See Walk Up in the Book area for top access info.
content.location: At the left end of the area, this is the double crack system.

climbs.name: Alphonsus
climbs.fa: Adam Harkins, Allyson Harkins, Patrick Harkins

content.description: Somewhat tricky scramble to the small ledge for the first clip. Climbing the right side of bolt line, there’s a small flake, climbing on the left side, there are some rounded ledges and and a few crimps. The crux is between clips 1 and 2.In memoriam of Evan Patrick Alphonsus Harkins, who got his whole family into climbing.
content.location: Left of Campbell and right of Five Times Fast

content.description:
Start on "Campbell"

  and after the second bolt traverse left across the wall following 7 wave bolts to the anchors of "Lefty"

  The route is mostly clean though the black section is especially chossy and dirty even by Cliff Drive standards.  

  Great for multipitch practice, though a 40m will be enough to lower the leader back to the ground.

pathTokens: Big and Small Crack Areas "AKA Lefty Wall"

content.description: The wide crack marks the left end of this small area and the left-facing dihedral marks the right end.
